title: MAJESTIC AIR CARGO low cost, perishable specialized, with zero intermediation.
content:
Majestic Air Cargo is a vertically integrated aviation logistics system designed to advance MAJESTIC’s hemispheric infrastructure objectives, delivering speed, control, and strategic clarity across production, logistics, and technology corridors. By embedding air freight directly into the platform architecture, Majestic eliminates third-party dependencies, compresses delivery timelines, and enables simulation-driven routing that aligns with perishability profiles, demand signals, and geopolitical conditions. Compared to outsourced models, this structure reduces fixed costs by up to 28%, improves corridor uptime, and enhances investor-grade visibility into logistics performance.
The platform leverages a shared intelligence layer with FRESH-24, including real-time demand forecasting, perishability scoring, and corridor simulation engines. This unified data architecture allows Majestic Air Cargo to dynamically adjust flight schedules, optimize load factors, and prioritize cargo based on shelf life, urgency, and market-side volatility. Every shipment is tagged with predictive routing logic, enabling the airline to reroute in response to customs delays, weather disruptions, or corridor fatigue, turning data into a tactical asset. The same orchestration engine that powers FRESH-24’s supplier-buyer dynamics also guides aircraft utilization, cold-chain integrity, and cargo sequencing, ensuring that both platforms operate as a synchronized logistics ecosystem.
The Caribbean–South America corridor is a strategic anchor for Majestic’s early deployment. Despite geographic proximity, the region suffers from fragmented infrastructure, inconsistent customs protocols, and limited cold-chain capacity. Majestic Air Cargo addresses these gaps by deploying specialized aircraft, digitized clearance workflows, and corridor-specific governance logic. Integrated with FRESH-24’s real-time analytics, the airline can forecast demand spikes, pre-clear customs documentation, and dynamically allocate aircraft to high-yield routes, transforming what was once a logistical bottleneck into a competitive advantage.

title: Majestic Air Cargo is built around a clear set of objectives: perishable specialization, low-cost operations, minimal intermediation, and democratized access to air freight. The platform is designed to bring general cargo accessibility to the level of passenger flights, offering predictable schedules, transparent pricing, and corridor-level service guarantees. While FRESH-24 remains the anchor client, Majestic is open to third-party shippers, SMEs, and regional producers, creating a scalable logistics backbone for the broader hemispheric economy. The shared technology stack ensures that external customers benefit from the same predictive routing, compliance automation, and ESG tracking that powers MAJESTIC’s internal operations.

The management team behind Majestic Air Cargo brings decades of aviation experience, spanning commercial operations, cargo optimization, regulatory compliance, and fleet management. Their expertise ensures that the airline is not only operationally sound but strategically aligned with MAJESTIC’s modular governance and corridor activation logic. From aircraft selection to route planning and customs integration, every decision reflects a deep understanding of both aviation mechanics and platform economics.

Looking ahead, Majestic Air Cargo will explore intermodal integration opportunities, linking air corridors with rail, maritime, and last-mile logistics to create seamless, multi-layered trade flows. This next phase will also include ESG-linked fleet upgrades, AI-driven load optimization, and corridor-specific carbon tracking, ensuring that growth is not only scalable, but sustainable. The shared data infrastructure between Majestic and FRESH-24 will continue to evolve, enabling predictive risk modeling, automated compliance workflows, and real-time performance dashboards across every corridor, aircraft, and shipment.
INDUSTRY OVERVIEW
content:
The global air cargo industry in 2025 is undergoing a strategic transformation, driven by e-commerce acceleration, perishables demand, and the need for resilient, tech-enabled logistics infrastructure. Air cargo volumes are projected to reach 80 million tonnes, marking a 5.8% year-over-year growth, with revenues expected to hit $157 billion globally (New Bloom Solutions, “Colombia Keeps the U.S. Floral Industry Blooming: Why 80% of America’s Flowers Start Here,” New Bloom Solutions, accessed September 11, 2025.). Latin America and the Caribbean are leading this surge, posting a 12.5% YoY increase in international cargo traffic, driven by perishables, nearshoring, and regional trade realignment (International Air Transport Association (IATA), “Air Cargo Market Analysis – April 2025,” IATA, accessed September 16, 2025. https://www.iata.org/en/iata-repository/publications/economic-reports/air-cargo-market-analysis-april-2025).
Majestic Air Cargo enters this landscape with a dual-market focus: anchoring operations in Colombia’s robust internal market while leveraging corridor-level agility to expand across the Americas. Colombia alone handles over 580,000 tons of air cargo annually, with perishables, especially fresh-cut flowers, accounting for 90% of outbound volume (Air Cargo Week, “Avianca Cargo Becomes Top Flower Carrier from Colombia to the US,” Air Cargo Week, accessed September 16, 2025. https://aircargoweek.com/avianca-cargo-becomes-top-flower-carrier-from-colombia-to-the-us). This internal demand is amplified by FRESH-24’s projected $1.2B in annual throughput, creating a stable, high-frequency baseline for Majestic’s initial deployment.
Externally, the rise of cross-border e-commerce, pharmaceutical cold chains, and time-sensitive industrial goods is reshaping air cargo priorities. E-commerce now drives 20% of global air cargo volumes (Air Cargo Week, “The E-Commerce Boom: Driving Demand for Air Cargo Services,” Air Cargo Week, accessed September 16, 2025. https://aircargoweek.com/the-e-commerce-boom-driving-demand-for-air-cargo-services), with Latin America among the fastest-growing regions due to high smartphone penetration and expanding fulfillment infrastructure. Perishable goods, including produce, seafood, and specialty exports like asparagus, have seen volume increases of over 21% in key corridors such as Lima–Madrid and Bogotá–Miami. These trends align directly with Majestic’s specialization in temperature-sensitive cargo and its integration with FRESH-24’s perishability scoring and simulation logic.
Technological convergence is redefining competitiveness. AI-driven demand forecasting, automated customs workflows, and real-time cargo orchestration are no longer optional, they’re foundational. Majestic Air Cargo leverages a shared intelligence layer with FRESH-24, enabling predictive routing, dynamic load optimization, and corridor-specific compliance automation. This not only reduces spoilage and delays but also positions Majestic as a logistics intelligence system rather than a conventional carrier.
With jet fuel costs down 21.2% YoY (International Air Transport Association (IATA), “Air Cargo Market Analysis – April 2025,” IATA, accessed September 16, 2025. https://www.iata.org/en/iata-repository/publications/economic-reports/air-cargo-market-analysis-april-2025), and capacity growth lagging behind demand, operators with dedicated fleets and corridor-level control, like Majestic, are poised to capture margin and market share. The platform’s modular architecture allows rapid activation in underserved corridors such as the Caribbean–South America bridge, where infrastructure gaps and customs friction have historically constrained growth.

title: United States – Target Market Analysis
content:
The United States remains the most mature and dynamic air cargo market in the world, offering both scale and strategic depth for Majestic Air Cargo’s hemispheric logistics ambitions. With a projected GDP of $27.1 trillion in 2025, the U.S. economy continues to grow steadily at 2.1%, supported by resilient consumer spending and a stable labor market (International Monetary Fund (IMF), “World Economic Outlook Database – April 2025,” IMF, accessed September 16, 2025.). Urbanization exceeds 82%, and a population of over 334 million, with a median household income of $78,500, drives consistent demand for both passenger and cargo aviation services (World Bank, “Urban Population (% of Total Population) – United States,” World Bank Data, accessed September 16, 2025.).
Air travel in the U.S. is rebounding strongly post-pandemic, with domestic passenger enplanements expected to reach 980 million this year. Business travel is regaining momentum, forecasted to grow 4.0% year-over-year, while international inbound visits are surging at 8.8%, fueled by major upcoming events like the 2026 FIFA World Cup and the 2028 Olympics (Air Cargo Week, “The E-Commerce Boom: Driving Demand for Air Cargo Services,” Air Cargo Week.). These trends not only boost passenger volumes but also stimulate cargo flows, particularly in high-frequency corridors such as New York–Los Angeles, Atlanta–Chicago, and Dallas–Denver.
From a cargo perspective, the U.S. handles over 8 billion freight ton-miles annually, with e-commerce now accounting for 20% of total air cargo volume (Bureau of Transportation Statistics, “Air Cargo Summary Data,” U.S. Department of Transportation. https://www.bts.gov/topics/freight-transportation/air-cargo). Major hubs like Memphis (FedEx), Louisville (UPS), Miami (LATAM gateway), and Los Angeles (Asia-Pacific trade) anchor a network that is both high-capacity and highly specialized. Despite its scale, the market continues to evolve, favoring carriers that offer corridor-level control, perishables specialization, and tech-enabled routing. With jet fuel costs down 21.2% year-over-year (International Air Transport Association (IATA), “Air Cargo Market Analysis – April 2025,” IATA, https://www.iata.org/en/iata-repository/publications/economic-reports/air-cargo-market-analysis-april-2025), operators with dedicated fleets and predictive load optimization are positioned to capture margin and market share.

title: Colombia – Target Market Analysis
content:
Colombia represents a high-potential logistics hub for Majestic Air Cargo, offering a rare combination of strong internal demand, geographic centrality, and accelerating aviation infrastructure. With a projected GDP of $401 billion in 2025, Colombia’s economy continues to expand at a steady 3.1% annual growth rate ( Statista, “Gross domestic product (GDP) in Colombia from 1987 to 2028,” Statista, https://www.statista.com/statistics/263716/gross-domestic-product-gdp-in-colombia), driven by diversified exports, rising consumer demand, and increased foreign investment. The country’s population stands at 52 million (Worldometer, “Colombia Population (2025),” Worldometer. https://www.worldometers.info/world-population/colombia-population/), with over 77% urbanization()WorldData.info, “Population Growth in Colombia,” WorldData. https://www.worlddata.info/america/colombia/populationgrowth.php, and a growing middle class whose purchasing power is reflected in a median household income of $9,800 USD, up 4.2% YoY (Statista, “Median household income in Colombia from 2010 to 2028,” Statista. https://www.statista.com/statistics/1324904/colombia-median-household-income), signaling rising domestic consumption and travel propensity.
The aviation sector is a cornerstone of Colombia’s economic engine, contributing $15.5 billion to GDP and supporting over 920,000 jobs across airlines, airports, tourism, and logistics (Finance Colombia, “Bogotá to Host IATA’s Wings of Change Aviation Industry Event,” Finance Colombia. https://www.financecolombia.com/bogota-to-host-iatas-wings-of-change-aviation-industry-event). Air travel demand continues to surge, in the first four months of 2025 alone, Colombia transported 18.2 million passengers, a 3.4% increase over the same period in 2024. International traffic rose by 600,000 passengers, reflecting Colombia’s growing appeal as both a tourism and trade gateway (Aviación al Día, “Colombia Mobilized Over 18 Million Air Passengers in First Four Months of 2025,” https://aviacionaldia.com/en/2025/05/colombia-mobilized-over-18-million-air-passengers-in-first-four-months-of-2025.html). Cargo volumes also expanded, with 326,000 tons moved, up 3.1% YoY, reinforcing the country’s role in regional supply chains (Aviacionline, “Air Travel in Colombia Sees Steady Growth in Early 2025,”. https://www.aviacionline.com/air-travel-in-colombia-sees-steady-growth-in-early-2025).
Colombia’s air cargo market is anchored by perishables, especially fresh-cut flowers, which account for 90% of outbound air freight, with total annual cargo volumes exceeding 580,000 tons (Air Cargo Week, “Avianca Cargo Becomes Top Flower Carrier from Colombia to the US,” Air Cargo Week.
https://aircargoweek.com/avianca-cargo-becomes-top-flower-carrier-from-colombia-to-the-us). FRESH-24’s projected $1.2B in annual throughput will serve as a stable internal anchor for Majestic Air Cargo, enabling high-frequency, short-haul operations with predictable load factors and perishability-driven routing. The integration of Majestic’s fleet with FRESH-24’s simulation engine allows for real-time cargo orchestration, minimizing spoilage and optimizing corridor performance.
Origination and Destination (O&D) traffic patterns further validate Colombia’s strategic positioning. 77% of passenger traffic is domestic, but international flows are growing rapidly, especially to North America (44%), Latin America (40%), and Europe (16%) (International Air Transport Association (IATA), “The Value of Air Transport to Colombia,” IATA. https://www.iata.org/en/iata-repository/publications/economic-reports/the-value-of-air-transport-to-colombia/). Top international destinations include Miami, Madrid, Mexico City, New York, and Panama City, all of which align with Majestic’s corridor activation logic. These routes not only support passenger flows but also represent high-yield cargo corridors for perishables, pharma, and e-commerce.
Colombia’s aviation infrastructure is expanding to meet demand. Airports like El Dorado (BOG), José María Córdova (MDE), and Alfonso Bonilla Aragón (CLO) are investing in cargo terminals, cold-chain facilities, and digital customs integration. With average airfare costs down 6.6% over the past decade, and increased accessibility across rural and secondary cities, Colombia is becoming a logistics launchpad, not just for domestic distribution, but for hemispheric trade.

title: COMPETITIVE ANALYSIS
content:
Majestic Air Cargo enters a Latin American market defined by rapid growth, infrastructure modernization, and intensifying competition among legacy carriers, regional operators, and platform-driven logistics players. The dominant incumbents, LATAM Cargo, Avianca Cargo, Copa Airlines Cargo, and MercadoLibre Logistics, each bring distinct strengths to the table, from expansive fleets and established cold-chain networks to deep regional connectivity and e-commerce integration. However, they also face structural limitations: legacy systems, constrained perishables handling, and limited corridor-level orchestration.
LATAM and Avianca lead in scale and perishables exports, particularly in Brazil and Colombia, but struggle to optimize inbound flows and dynamic routing. Copa’s regional reach is strong, yet its belly-only model restricts cargo flexibility. Meanwhile, MercadoLibre is reshaping logistics through tech and fulfillment, but lacks direct control over air cargo operations.

title: Incumbent Airlines in the Latin American Marketplace (2025)
content:
Latin America’s aviation landscape is dominated by a handful of incumbent carriers that have shaped regional connectivity, cargo flows, and consumer expectations over the past two decades. These airlines, LATAM, Avianca, Copa Airlines, Azul, Gol, Volaris, and Viva-Aerobus, represent both opportunities and constraint for new entrants like Majestic Air Cargo. While they offer scale, infrastructure, and brand recognition, they also suffer from legacy inefficiencies, fragmented cargo strategies, and limited perishables specialization. Understanding their operational models, market positioning, and strategic blind spots is essential to defining Majestic’s competitive edge.
LATAM Airlines Group
LATAM is the largest airline group in Latin America, operating across Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Peru, and Ecuador. It holds a commanding 52% market share at São Paulo Guarulhos (GRU) and maintains dominant positions in Santiago and Lima. In 2024, LATAM operated 553,191 flights, with a 7% YoY increase in frequency, and served 694 routes, though this number declined slightly due to network optimization.
Its fleet includes 35 narrowbody and 23 widebody aircraft, with an average age of 8.4 years, and no regional jets or turboprops. LATAM’s aircraft are optimized for long-haul and high-density routes but lack specialization in perishables or short-haul cargo.
Avianca
Avianca is Colombia’s flagship carrier and a regional powerhouse, operating 169 routes to 82 destinations, including 43 domestic and 37 international routes. It holds a dominant position in Colombia, with 80 active routes and a strong presence in the U.S.–Latin America corridor, where it added 8,000 weekly seats in 2025.
Its fleet includes 134 Airbus A320 family aircraft, 15 Boeing 787s, and 14 Airbus A330s, with an average fleet age of 7.2 years. Avianca’s widebody aircraft are used on premium transcontinental routes, while narrowbodies dominate regional operations.
Schedules are robust, with daily frequencies on key U.S. routes like Miami–Bogotá and New York–Medellín, and 3–4x weekly service on secondary routes.
Despite its strength in outbound perishables, especially flowers, Avianca’s corridor logic remains outbound-centric, with limited inbound optimization and perishables diversity. Majestic’s bidirectional perishables routing and simulation logic offer a clear advantage.
Copa Airlines
Copa Airlines operates from its Panama City hub, serving 88 destinations in 32 countries with 375+ daily flights. It holds a strategic position in short-haul connectivity across Central and South America, but lacks a dedicated freighter fleet.
Copa’s fleet consists of 114 aircraft, primarily Boeing 737 MAX 8s, with an average age of 6.1 years. The uniform fleet supports operational efficiency but limits cargo flexibility, especially for perishables and oversized freight.
Copa’s belly-only cargo model restricts perishables throughput and corridor adaptability.
Azul Linhas Aéreas
Azul is Brazil’s largest carrier by network coverage, serving 160+ destinations with 1,000 daily flights. It holds a 41.8% market share on domestic routes, with strong performance in underserved regional markets.
Azul’s fleet includes 45 Embraer E2 jets, 22 Airbus A330neos, and multiple ATR turboprops, with an average fleet age of 6.7 years. This mix supports regional access and cold-chain logistics, though perishables handling remains secondary.
Gol Linhas Aéreas
Gol operates 74 destinations with a fleet of 139 Boeing 737s, including 7 freighters, and maintains hubs in São Paulo, Brasília, and Rio de Janeiro. It holds a 26.9% market share in Brazil, down from its peak, and is undergoing restructuring under Chapter 11.
Gol’s fleet includes 54 Boeing 737 MAX 8s, with an average age of 8.2 years, and 30 MAX 10s on order. Its all-737 strategy supports cost efficiency but limits perishables handling and corridor flexibility.
Volaris & Viva-Aerobus
These Mexican ULCCs dominate domestic traffic, with Volaris holding 42% and Viva-Aerobus 36% of the market. Volaris operates 113 Airbus aircraft, 61% of which are NEO models, while Viva-Aerobus has 70 aircraft, including A320s and A321neos, with an average age of 6.9 years.
Schedules are dense on domestic routes, with 3–5x daily frequencies between major cities, but international coverage remains limited.

title: Barriers to Market Entry in Latin American Air Cargo (2025)
content:
While Latin America presents high-growth potential for air cargo, market entry is shaped by a complex web of regulatory, operational, and competitive constraints. These barriers vary by country but share common themes: limited slot availability at major hubs, restrictive bilateral agreements, and entrenched incumbent positioning.
Major airports like São Paulo (GRU), Mexico City (NLU), Bogotá (BOG), and Santiago (SCL) operate near capacity, with slot allocation tightly controlled by national aviation authorities. New entrants face challenges securing peak-hour slots, especially for freighter operations, which are deprioritized in favor of passenger traffic. Infrastructure constraints, such as limited cold-chain terminals and outdated cargo handling systems, further restrict operational flexibility.
Latin America’s air transport liberalization remains fragmented. While some countries have embraced open skies (e.g., Chile, Panama), others maintain restrictive bilateral air service agreements that limit foreign carrier frequencies, cargo rights, and route access. For example, Brazil and Argentina require reciprocity clauses and often cap third/fourth freedom rights, complicating multi-stop corridor activation. These agreements can delay route launches and require diplomatic negotiation or strategic partnerships.
Customs procedures across the region are inconsistent, with varying clearance times, documentation requirements, and inspection protocols. In countries like Peru and Ecuador, collaborative models between cargo operators and customs (e.g., Talma’s integration with Peruvian authorities) have improved throughput, but such models are not yet widespread. Regulatory fragmentation increases compliance costs and reduces predictability, especially for perishables and pharma.
Incumbent carriers such as LATAM, Avianca Cargo, and Copa Airlines benefit from preferential access to slots, legacy infrastructure, and long-standing government relationships. Their dominance in key hubs creates informal barriers to entry, including lobbying influence and priority in cargo terminal access. Additionally, their scale allows them to undercut pricing on high-volume lanes, making it difficult for new entrants to compete on cost alone.

title: OPPORTUNITY
content:
Majestic Air Cargo enters the Latin American aviation and logistics market with a precision-first model designed to serve a captive, underserved segment: perishables producers, platform operators, and corridor-based trade systems. While incumbents dominate by volume, Majestic is engineered for strategic depth, activating modular corridors, optimizing freshness-sensitive cargo, and embedding simulation-driven resilience into every route. The opportunity is not just market share, it’s market orchestration.
FRESH-24, Majestic’s sister company, is the primary user and strategic driver of corridor activation. As a perishables platform coordinating high-frequency trade between producers and buyers across the Americas, FRESH-24 demands a logistics backbone that guarantees freshness, predictability, and bidirectional flow. Existing carriers cannot meet these standards. Their models are outbound-centric, generalized, and reactive.
Majestic fills this gap by offering perishables-first routing, ESG-compliant fleet logic, and real-time corridor orchestration. FRESH-24’s internal demand engine feeds directly into Majestic’s simulation layer, enabling dynamic routing based on perishables type, temperature sensitivity, and buyer urgency. This transforms logistics from a cost center into a strategic asset.
Majestic Air Cargo is the logistics engine of FILPROC, Fully Integrated Production and Logistic Corridors, serving as the connective tissue between mapped production nodes and activated demand centers across the Americas. While FILPROC fuses production, logistics, and technology into a single intelligent infrastructure, Majestic is the carrier that operationalizes this intelligence in motion. It transforms FILPROC’s corridor logic into real-world routing, ensuring that perishables and high-value goods move with precision, speed, and strategic control.
Majestic’s fleet is designed around perishables-first logic, optimized for temperature-sensitive cargo and synchronized with harvest-to-market cycles. Every route is modeled through FILPROC’s simulation engines, allowing Majestic to dynamically activate corridors based on real-time supply signals from farms, fisheries, and manufacturing hubs. This eliminates latency and replaces static scheduling with predictive orchestration.
Through FILPROC’s logistics synchronization layer, Majestic integrates cold-chain systems, bonded warehousing, customs pre-clearance, and multimodal handoffs into a unified routing protocol. Whether moving flowers from Bogotá, seafood from Kingston, or produce from Querétaro, Majestic ensures that every shipment is tracked, quality-assured, and ESG-compliant. Its modular routing logic allows corridors to be replicated rapidly across new geographies and product categories.
On the technology front, Majestic interfaces directly with FILPROC’s backbone, leveraging AI-driven production mapping, real-time orchestration, and dashboards to optimize every flight. It also powers the logistics layer for FRESH-24, enabling institutional buyers, auction platforms, and e-commerce channels to access live routing, traceability, and impact metrics.
The introduction of a cargo low-cost carrier (CLCC) in Latin America would represent a seismic shift in the region’s air logistics landscape. Currently, the market is dominated by legacy carriers with high fixed costs, rigid scheduling, and generalized service models that prioritize volume over precision. A CLCC, built around modular routing, lean operations, and perishables-first logic, would democratize access to air cargo, especially for small and mid-sized producers, regional platforms, and underserved corridors.
By stripping away legacy overhead and optimizing for short-haul, high-frequency routes, a CLCC could reduce cost-per-kilo by 20–35%, unlocking new demand from captive markets previously priced out of air transport. It would also introduce competitive pressure on incumbents, forcing them to rethink pricing, perishables handling, and corridor responsiveness. For platforms like FRESH-24, a CLCC offers direct control, real-time routing, and scalable access to secondary cities, transforming logistics from a bottleneck into a growth engine. In essence, the arrival of a cargo low-cost carrier wouldn’t just disrupt the market, it would expand it.

At its core, Majestic is engineered to meet the high-frequency, freshness-sensitive demands of FRESH-24, its primary client, by activating modular corridors that synchronize production nodes with buyer markets across the Americas. title: Operational description
content:
Operational bases:
Greensboro’s Piedmont Triad International Airport (GSO).
GSO is Majestic Air Cargo’s primary U.S. base. Located at the heart of North Carolina’s manufacturing and agricultural belt, GSO provides direct access to key perishables markets, multimodal infrastructure, and uncongested airspace, making it ideal for time-sensitive cargo operations.
GSO’s cargo facilities are equipped with bonded warehousing, cold-chain handling, and customs pre-clearance, enabling Majestic to synchronize inbound perishables from Latin America with outbound replenishment and distribution across the U.S. Southeast. Miami International Airport (MIA)
serves as Majestic Air Cargo’s U.S secondary base of operations, anchoring its perishables entry point into the United States and enabling high-frequency connectivity across the Americas, Europe, and Asia. As the largest perishables hub in the U.S., MIA handles over 70% of all airborne perishables entering the country, making it indispensable for FRESH-24’s inbound routing and corridor activation.
MIA’s infrastructure is purpose-built for perishables logistics. The airport is home to the largest on-airport cooler in North America and is currently expanding with a 340,000 sq ft Future-Ready Phytosanitary and Cold Chain Processing Facility, capable of treating over 20,000 TEUs per year and storing more than 35,000 pallet positions. This facility integrates USDA-approved irradiation, cold storage, and high-throughput logistics services, ensuring compliance, shelf-life extension, and rapid distribution for temperature-sensitive cargo.
With direct connections to over 160 destinations, frequent routes to Latin America and the Caribbean, and efficient links to Port-Miami and ground networks, this location enables quick customs clearance, flexible scheduling, and ESG-compliant routes, ideal for high-value or time-sensitive cargo.
Rionegro’s international airport “Jose Maria Cordoba” (MDE)
Located near Medellin, this airport is the second in number of operations after Bogota’s, from here 18% of all fresh cut flowers are exported to north America, its central location provides connection to major production centers. Being the second airport in Colombia, still is very under used, allowing the opportunity to grow the market departing from there, taking the advantage of Bogota’s airport which is almost completely at full capacity.
Alfonso Bonilla Aragón International Airport (CLO)

While not as saturated as Bogotá’s El Dorado, Cali offers faster turnaround times, lower slot competition, and increasing investment in cargo handling capabilities. Its location also enables multimodal integration with Colombia’s 4G and 5G infrastructure projects, connecting producers to ports, highways, and regional airports with improved efficiency.

Positioned at the heart of Antioquia’s floriculture and agricultural belt, MDE handles a significant share of the country’s fresh-cut flower exports, especially during peak seasons like Valentine’s Day and Mother’s Day. Its proximity to high-density production zones makes it an ideal launch point for FILPROC corridors serving North America, Central America, and the Caribbean.
MDE’s cargo terminal supports over 92,000 tons of international freight annually, with infrastructure tailored for perishables, including cold-chain facilities, customs pre-clearance, and phytosanitary inspection zones. The airport’s ICAO 4F classification and ability to accommodate widebody freighters ensure operational flexibility and scalability for Majestic’s perishables-first fleet.
For FRESH-24, MDE functions as a primary export gateway, enabling synchronized harvest-to-market cycles and direct access to buyers via Majestic’s simulation-driven routing. title: PRODUCT OFFERING
content:
Majestic air cargo will provide the services through 3 different models:
Direct Charter
The Direct Charter model is Majestic Air Cargo’s core operational and commercial modality, designed to deliver dedicated, high-performance air logistics services to its primary client, FRESH-24. Under this model, Majestic operates full aircraft charters on a corridor-by-corridor basis, activated through FILPROC’s simulation engine and tailored to perishables-first routing logic. Each flight is scheduled based on real-time demand signals, harvest cycles, and buyer-side requirement, ensuring unmatched freshness, speed, and strategic control.
As the primary revenue stream, Direct Charter flights are fully contracted by FRESH-24, enabling synchronized logistics across mapped production nodes and institutional buyers. These flights include the full suite of Majestic’s integrated services:
Cold-chain integrity and temperature-controlled handling
Customs pre-clearance and bonded warehousing
Simulation-driven scheduling and corridor optimization
Platform integration for auction cycles and e-commerce fulfillment.
Indirect Charter

This model enables year-round access to Majestic’s integrated logistics services for producers, exporters, and platforms who operate at lower volumes but require reliability, speed, and perishables-first handling, also to sell available space in the routes chartered by FRESH-24.
Under this structure, Majestic partners with a General Sales Agent (GSA), an embedded component of the Majestic program who charters round-trip aircraft capacity and then sells payload space by the kilogram to qualified customers. These clients benefit from all the service features of the Direct Charter model.

title: AIRCRAFT SELECTION
content:
Based on the projected routes, the aircraft selection was to establish the most efficient aircraft in the following variables:
Hot and high operation
Fuel efficiency
Maintenance hour per cycle, 3 to 5 flight hours optimum ratio
Available lifetime and OEM long term support
Aircraft availability
Other operators
Reliability
Payload vs range
A-321P2F (First option)
The Airbus A321P2F (Passenger-to-Freighter conversion) is a highly efficient, narrow-body cargo aircraft optimized for medium-haul operations, making it an ideal fit for Majestic Air Cargo’s perishables-first corridor strategy. With a payload capacity of up to 28 tonnes and 24 container positions across its main and lower decks, it offers a strong balance between volume and fuel efficiency. Its range of approximately 2,000 nautical miles enables high-frequency routing across Latin America, the Caribbean, and southern U.S. markets, supporting both Direct and Indirect Charter models with precision and reliability.
Boeing 757-200P2F (second option)
The Boeing 757-200P2F is a mid-size, narrow-body freighter known for its exceptional payload-to-range ratio, making it a versatile asset for Majestic’s longer perishables corridors and high-volume charter operations. With a maximum payload capacity of up to 39,800 kg (87,700 lbs) and a range of approximately 3,150 nautical miles (5,830 km) fully loaded, it supports transcontinental and deep regional routes with efficiency and reliability. The aircraft accommodates 15 standard ULD positions on the main deck, plus additional bulk cargo in the lower hold, allowing for flexible configuration of perishables, pharma, and general cargo
Boeing 777 Freighter
The Boeing 777 Freighter is the world’s most capable twin-engine cargo aircraft, purpose-built for long-range, high-payload operations. With a maximum revenue payload of up to 102 tonnes and a range of approximately 4,970 nautical miles, it enables nonstop connectivity between Latin America and major global markets such as Europe, Asia, and North America. The aircraft supports 31 main deck and 10 lower deck pallet positions, offering exceptional volumetric capacity for perishables, pharma, and general cargo. Its fuel efficiency and reliability make it a preferred choice for replacing older widebody freighters like the 747-400F, while maintaining superior economics and ESG compliance.
ROUTE STRUCTURE
Majestic Air Cargo serves FRESH-24 through a strategically engineered triangulated route structure connecting the United States, Colombia, and the Caribbean islands, designed to meet the platform’s perishables-first logistics requirements with precision and speed. These routes are activated via Majestic’s Direct Charter model, ensuring synchronized harvest-to-market cycles from Colombia’s agricultural hubs, rapid delivery to institutional buyers in the U.S., and redistribution or replenishment across key Caribbean nodes, all with cold-chain integrity and simulation-driven scheduling.

title: ADMINISTRATIVE, CUSTOMER SERVICE, AND LABOR FRAMEWORK
content:
Administrative Structure
Majestic Air Cargo’s administrative structure is built on a lean, high-performance framework that prioritizes real-time visibility, accountability, and operational clarity across all departments. At its core is a unified tech layer, combining proprietary systems and third-party platforms, to enable live tracking, automated workflows, and seamless data exchange. This infrastructure supports key operational axes including human resources management, compliance, traceability, and performance governance, ensuring that every process is auditable, responsive, and aligned with strategic objectives. By minimizing human error and maximizing process reliability, Majestic creates a logistics environment where decision-making is data-driven, and execution is frictionless.
Customer Service Model
Customer service model mirrors this operational philosophy, blending technology and human engagement to deliver premium support across all touchpoints. A third-party call center handles inbound inquiries with speed and professionalism, while commercial portfolio agents are empowered through integrated dashboards to resolve client needs proactively. Web-based channels with real-time chat, shipment tracking, and tailored response logic ensure that every customer interaction is transparent, efficient, and personalized. This multi-channel approach, underpinned by Majestic’s tech ecosystem, guarantees that service delivery is not only consistent, but strategically aligned with the company’s commitment to excellence and platform-driven logistics.
Labor structure and compensation
Pay Rates and Scales: Crew pay rates will align with industry averages to attract and retain skilled personnel. For other roles, salary bands will be linked to the minimum wage yet set above market minimums to promote employee commitment and responsibility, laying the foundation for a positive workplace culture.
Benefits: All employees will receive benefits as defined by internal policy, including performance-based bonuses tied to the achievement of KPIs, team accomplishments, and company financial results. A set percentage of net profit will be allocated annually for these benefits. Human Resources will also establish non-monetary incentives to further enhance the work environment.
Contracts and Employment Terms: All staff will hold direct contracts with Majestic Air Cargo. Salaries will be adjusted annually in line with the minimum wage indicator, ensuring equitable conditions and consistent benefit programs. The company is committed to a non-union labor structure, relying on competitive compensation and comprehensive benefits to promote employee satisfaction and retention.
Maintenance
Maintenance will be under third party contract until fleet size is enough to establish Majestic’s maintenance infrastructure:
Line: daily, weekly and “A” checks will be performed by a certified FAA shop, will be supervised and audited by the company’s internal maintenance structure.
Also, a mechanic must be a part of the crew to be the primary link with the maintenance response system and ensure reliability and continuous airworthiness.
Heavy checks will be performed with a certified MRO.
Flight operations
Will be performed under the requirements established under FAR 121, sufficient crews will be available to support the 24/7 operations with all safety standards.
Training also will be in accordance with the regulations and additional tools for skill development will be provided.
Fuel policies
As fuel represents more than 45% of the company’s cost structure, a fuel conservation program will be developed and established, all flight fuel consumption will be monitored and analyzed to prevent over burning or poor operation of the aircraft. This doesn’t represent any risk for the flight; all fuel quantities will be enough to fulfill the mission and will have a 10% extra fuel plus a minimum of an extra 1 hour of flight fuel.  Flight engineering ops will be monitoring and giving feedback in both directions with the crews to have reliable statistics that can provide information to make purchasing policies.
A substantial difference in the fuel price between Colombia and the U.S. is a constant, so a tankering system will be established to monitor permanently the fuel prices in departure / destination airports to load the most amount of fuel within the payload, weight and balance and commercial requirements for the flight.
Technology (IT, AI, WEB Services)
Majestic Air Cargo’s technology layer is the operational backbone of its perishables-first logistics model, designed to unify customer-facing interfaces, flight operations, administrative workflows, and financial governance into a single, integrated ecosystem. From the moment a customer initiates a reservation, whether through direct charter, indirect charter, or platform-based booking, the system activates a dynamic routing engine that aligns cargo requirements with available aircraft, corridor schedules, and perishables handling protocols. This front-end interface is seamlessly connected to Majestic’s flight operations module, which manages aircraft allocation, crew scheduling, route simulation, and cold-chain compliance in real time.
At the core of this architecture is a modular platform that synchronizes administrative tasks, including HR management, compliance tracking, and documentation, with flight and maintenance operations, ensuring that every component of the business operates under unified logic. Maintenance schedules are linked to aircraft utilization data and spare parts inventory, allowing predictive servicing and budget alignment. The system flags parts consumption against corridor profitability, enabling strategic decisions on fleet deployment and asset optimization. Safety and security protocols are embedded throughout the cargo lifecycle, with automated alerts for temperature deviations, customs anomalies, and route disruptions, ensuring traceability and integrity from origin to destination.
Financial operations are fully integrated into the platform, with a built-in payment gateway that supports multi-currency transactions, escrow logic for platform clients, and automated invoicing tied to cargo milestones. Budgeting tools correlate operational costs, fuel, crew, maintenance, and ground handling, with revenue streams from both direct and indirect charter models, providing real-time visibility into margin performance and corridor ROI. This holistic tech layer transforms Majestic from a traditional air cargo operator into a digitally orchestrated logistics engine, where every decision is data-driven, every process is traceable, and every shipment is part of a larger strategic flow.

title: FINANCIAL ANALYSIS
content:
Revenue Streams
Direct Charter
The Direct Charter product is designed for enterprise-level clients capable of securing a full round-trip aircraft originating from strategic hubs such as Rionegro. Under this model, the customer defines the cargo volume within aircraft payload limits, with Majestic providing end-to-end operational support, including perishables processing, cold chain integrity, security screening, aircraft loading/unloading, and all aeronautical and airport services.
This product is ideal for high-season perishables exports (e.g., floriculture, fresh produce) where timing, shelf-life, and market urgency demand dedicated lift capacity.
Pricing Model:
Base Fare + Variable Fare + Ancillary Costs = Operational Cost
Operational Cost × Profit Margin (15–20%) = Sale Price
The Direct Charter model within Majestic Air Cargo is structured into two distinct variants: Fixed Contract and Occasional Contract. The Fixed Contract is deployed in strategic partnership with Fresh24, positioning Majestic as its primary air logistics provider for perishables. This variant operates with lower profit margins, intentionally designed to enhance product competitiveness and ensure consistent corridor activation aligned with shelf-life and market urgency. In contrast, the Occasional Contract serves ad-hoc clients requiring dedicated lift capacity on a non-recurring basis. Due to the unpredictability of demand and routing complexity, this variant carries higher profit margins to offset forecasting challenges and operational risk, while still maintaining Majestic’s standards for cold chain integrity and service reliability.
Indirect Charter – Payload Fractionalization via GSA Network
The Indirect Charter product serves mid-sized and SME exporters with consistent but fractional cargo needs. Flights are chartered round-trip by a General Sales Agent (GSA), who assumes commercial risk and resells payload capacity by kilogram to multiple clients. All operational services, cold chain control, cargo handling, and security, mirror those of the Direct Charter.
This model supports year-round perishables flow, balancing corridor occupancy and market accessibility.
Pricing Model:
Base Fare + Variable Fare + Ancillary Costs = Operational Cost
Operational Cost × Route Index × Profit Margin = Sale Price per kg
The Route Index adjusts pricing based on corridor length, airport fees, traffic density, and perishables sensitivity. It ensures competitive pricing while preserving margins and service quality.
Majestic Air Cargo will establish its own dedicated General Sales Agent (GSA) to manage and commercialize the Indirect Charter flight model across its core corridor network. This internal GSA will be responsible for optimizing payload distribution, pricing per kilogram, and ensuring alignment with perishables demand signals from Fresh24. However, Majestic remains strategically open to collaborating with external GSAs in cases where routes fall outside its dedicated corridor structure or where mutual benefits, such as lower operational costs, superior infrastructure access, or enhanced efficiency metrics, justify external engagement. This hybrid approach ensures both control and flexibility, allowing Majestic to maximize aircraft occupancy, preserve service quality, and expand market reach without compromising its perishables-first logistics standard.
Value-Added Services
Majestic offers modular add-ons to enhance cargo integrity and traceability:
Temporary Cold Storage – Buffer zones at origin/destination for perishables staging
Live Cargo Tracking – Real-time visibility across air and ground segments

title: Cost Structure
content:

Operational Costs

Third-Party Services: Includes contracted support for specialized tasks such as perishables handling, customs coordination, and airport logistics.

Indirect Costs

Unforeseen Reserves: Allocated for contingency planning, risk mitigation, and geopolitical volatility buffering.
These costs enable Majestic to maintain strategic clarity, investor confidence, and regulatory agility across hemispheric operations.
Variable Costs

Fuel: The dominant cost driver, influenced by route length, aircraft type, and fuel market volatility. Majestic uses simulation models to optimize fuel efficiency across corridors.
Ground Operations: Includes airport fees, cargo handling, perishables staging, and cold chain logistics at origin and destination.
Aeronautical Costs: Covers airspace navigation fees, landing charges, and regulatory levies.
Maintenance per Cycle: Reflects wear-and-tear costs tied to flight frequency and aircraft utilization.
Crew Support: Includes travel, lodging, and per diem for flight crews operating across multi-corridor routes.
Majestic’s pricing engine incorporates these variable costs into both direct and indirect charter models, adjusting for perishables sensitivity, corridor saturation, and route complexity.

title: RISK ANALYSIS
content: The following chapter presents a comprehensive risk analysis for Majestic Air Cargo, structured across six critical domains: market access, competitive landscape, team and management capacity, financial resilience, operational integrity, and regulatory/political exposure. Each area has been evaluated to identify potential vulnerabilities that could impact corridor activation, service continuity, or strategic scalability. By mapping these risks against Majestic’s modular architecture and perishables-first mission, the analysis provides a clear foundation for mitigation planning, investor confidence, and long-term platform resilience.

title: Market Risk Analysis:
content:
Access to Objective Market: Majestic faces potential barriers in reaching institutional buyers and high-volume clients outside its core platform ecosystem. Limited brand recognition, regulatory hurdles, or lack of bilateral agreements could restrict access to strategic markets, impacting corridor activation and revenue scalability.
Niche Market Dependency (FRESH-24) Reliance on FRESH-24 as a primary client creates concentration risk. While the partnership drives initial growth, overdependence on a single perishable platform may expose Majestic to volatility in platform performance, contract renegotiations, or strategic shifts that could affect flight volumes and financial stability.
Traditional Market Structure Dependency (MIA–Ground Transport): Majestic’s routing through legacy corridors like Miami–Grenada may be constrained by entrenched operators, slot limitations, and outdated customs protocols. This dependency can reduce flexibility, increase operational costs, and limit differentiation in service delivery.
Seasonal Offer–Demand Imbalance: Perishables logistics is inherently cyclical, with peak seasons (e.g., Valentine’s Day, Mother’s Day) driving high demand and off-peak periods resulting in underutilized capacity. Without dynamic scheduling and diversified cargo sources, Majestic risks inefficient fleet usage and margin compression.
No Compensation (Return) Cargo: Many northbound perishables routes lack corresponding southbound cargo flows, leading to empty return legs and reduced aircraft utilization. Without compensation cargo or strategic backhaul planning, Majestic may face elevated cost-per-kilo metrics and diminished corridor profitability.
To address the risk of Access to Objective Market, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a layered strategy focused on affordability, credibility, and cross-sector adaptability. The low-cost strategy positions Majestic as a competitive alternative to legacy carriers, offering streamlined pricing and perishables-first service without compromising quality. This is reinforced by a flat-rate model, which simplifies client onboarding and reduces friction in contract negotiation, particularly for institutional buyers and regional exporters seeking predictable logistics costs.
Majestic further differentiates through specialization and reliability, emphasizing cold-chain integrity, simulation-driven routing, and ESG-compliant operations as core value propositions. These capabilities build trust and position Majestic as a premium yet accessible provider. To expand market reach, the company validates a multi-sector business model, adapting its tech and operational infrastructure to serve adjacent industries such as pharma, electronics, and humanitarian aid. All of this is underpinned by a modular operational model concept, which integrates flight ops, customer service, and administrative workflows into a unified system, ensuring consistency, scalability, and strategic alignment across every market entry point.
To mitigate the risk of Niche Market Dependency, particularly Majestic Air Cargo’s reliance on FRESH-24, a multi-pronged strategy has been designed to ensure operational resilience and revenue diversification. First, client portfolio diversification expands Majestic’s reach beyond perishables platforms by onboarding mid-sized exporters and regional clients through tailored service packages and GSA-led corridor activation. Simultaneously, corridor multiplexing enables parallel route deployment, allowing Majestic to serve multiple markets without disrupting core operations.
To safeguard contractual exposure, flex clauses are embedded into the FRESH-24 agreement, ensuring volume guarantees and performance-linked adjustments. Majestic also pursues cross-sector expansion, adapting its logistics infrastructure to serve adjacent industries such as pharma and humanitarian aid. These efforts are supported by an integrated risk monitoring dashboard, which tracks client concentration, corridor utilization, and seasonal volatility in real time. Finally, an investor-backed resilience fund provides financial cushioning against platform-side disruptions, reinforcing Majestic’s ability to scale sustainably while maintaining strategic independence.
To mitigate dependency on traditional market structures like MIA predominance for perishables entry, and Ground Transport accessibility, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a blend of corridor innovation, strategic partnerships, and technology-driven process redesign. By activating alternative routes, integrating digital customs workflows, and decentralizing ground operations, Majestic reduces exposure to legacy bottlenecks and monopolized infrastructure, while reducing costs, time and risks for the cargo. These strategies are reinforced by client education, multimodal planning, and regional hub development, ensuring that Majestic’s perishables-first model remains agile, scalable, and resilient across evolving logistics landscapes.
To mitigate Seasonal Offer–Demand Imbalance, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a modular strategy that blends dynamic scheduling, multi-sector cargo logic, and predictive demand planning. By adjusting fleet allocation, offering flexible charter packages, and incentivizing off-peak utilization, Majestic ensures consistent aircraft performance and revenue continuity. These strategies are reinforced by integrated forecasting tools and financial dashboards, allowing the company to anticipate volatility, optimize margins, and maintain strategic control across all seasonal cycles.
To mitigate the risk of No Return (Compensation) Cargo, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategic blend of cargo development, multimodal integration, dynamic pricing, and payload diversification. These strategies aim to fill southbound legs with viable cargo, stabilize aircraft utilization, and protect corridor-level margins. By embedding margin monitoring and route rebalancing into its tech layer, Majestic ensures that every flight, whether outbound or return, contributes to operational efficiency and strategic resilience.

title: Competitors risk Analysis

Price War: Competitors may aggressively lower rates to retain market share or block Majestic’s entry, especially in high-volume perishables corridors. This can erode margins and force unsustainable pricing strategies if not countered with differentiated value.

title: Financial Risk Analysis
content:
Intensive Capital Requirement: Majestic’s model demands significant upfront investment in aircraft, infrastructure, tech development, and corridor activation. This creates pressure on liquidity and requires disciplined capital planning to avoid overextension.
Lack or Delay in Fund Raising: Any delay in securing investor capital or credit facilities can stall key milestones, such as fleet acquisition, tech deployment, or market entry, impacting momentum and credibility.
Start-Up Risk Compensated with High Interest Rate: Early-stage financing may come with elevated interest rates or unfavorable terms due to perceived risk, increasing financial burden and reducing flexibility in capital allocation.
Financial Model Strength: Weak or unvalidated financial projections can undermine investor confidence and strategic decision-making. A robust, corridor-linked financial model is essential to justify ROI and guide resource deployment.
Payment Capability: Inability to meet short-term obligations, such as lease payments, vendor contracts, or payroll, can trigger operational disruptions and damage stakeholder trust.
Funds Management: Poor financial governance or lack of transparency in fund allocation can lead to inefficiencies, misaligned spending, and exposure to audit or compliance risks.
Company Low Profitability: If Majestic fails to reach breakeven within projected timelines, it may struggle to sustain operations, attract follow-on investment, or justify corridor expansion.
Low-Cost Model Non-Sustainability: While competitive pricing is key to market entry, an overly aggressive low-cost strategy may erode margins and compromise long-term viability if not balanced with value-added services.
Long-Term ROI: Majestic’s infrastructure-heavy model may require extended time horizons to realize full return on investment, demanding patient capital and strategic resilience.
Capital Scape: Uncontrolled capital outflows, whether through debt servicing, investor exits, or currency exposure, can destabilize financial planning and reduce reinvestment capacity.
Tax Structure: Inefficient or non-optimized tax frameworks across jurisdictions can reduce net profitability and expose Majestic to compliance risks or double taxation.
To mitigate Intensive Capital Requirement, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a lean, modular strategy built on efficient structure, diversified funding, and corridor-specific capital logic. By leveraging third-party capabilities, client-backed financing, and simulation-driven deployment, Majestic avoids overextension while preserving strategic control. These tactics ensure that every dollar invested is tied to measurable corridor impact, scalable infrastructure, and long-term platform resilience.
To mitigate Lack or Delay in Fund Raising, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a multi-pronged strategy built on controlled dilution, founder commitment, milestone logic, and strategic co-investment. By aligning capital deployment with corridor activation and leveraging short-term liquidity tools, Majestic preserves momentum and credibility, even under fundraising uncertainty. These tactics ensure that platform development remains resilient, investor-ready, and strategically paced across hemispheric expansion.
To mitigate Start-Up Risk Compensated with High Interest Rate, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a capital strategy built on flexibility, partner leverage, and milestone-based instruments. By combining refinancing options, collateral-backed partnerships, and revenue-linked repayment models, Majestic reduces financial strain while preserving growth momentum. These tactics ensure that early-stage capital supports strategic execution without compromising long-term profitability or founder control.
To ensure Financial Model Strength, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on external validation, dynamic updating, and operational alignment. By integrating scenario planning, due diligence readiness, and investor feedback, Majestic transforms its financial model into a strategic asset, capable of guiding capital deployment, corridor activation, and long-term platform growth. These tactics reinforce trust, adaptability, and precision across all financial engagements.
To ensure Payment Capability, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a disciplined strategy built on client-backed revenue, structured debt governance, and dynamic forecasting. By leveraging LOIs, loyalty contracts, and priority coverage protocols, Majestic maintains financial resilience across corridors. These tactics are reinforced by trust-building transparency, contingency reserves, and debt limitation logic, ensuring that every payment obligation is met with precision, credibility, and strategic foresight.
To mitigate Funds Management risk, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a governance-first strategy built on internal controls, planning discipline, and external validation. By integrating audit protocols, corridor-linked budgeting, and management limitations, Majestic ensures every dollar is traceable, justified, and strategically deployed. These tactics reinforce investor confidence, operational integrity, and long-term platform scalability.
To mitigate Company Low Profitability, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on commercial precision, cost discipline, and operational agility. By optimizing pricing, monitoring financial flows, and activating lean alternatives, Majestic ensures that each corridor contributes to platform-wide profitability. These tactics are reinforced by yield management, client segmentation, and simulation-driven cost control, transforming profitability from a static metric into a dynamic, scalable advantage.
To mitigate Low-Cost Model Non-Sustainability, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on financial agility, strategic partnerships, and corridor-level precision. By leveraging Fresh24’s ecosystem, activating tiered services, and outsourcing non-core functions, Majestic transforms cost discipline into a scalable advantage. These tactics ensure that low-cost entry does not compromise long-term viability, preserving margin, trust, and platform resilience across every corridor.
To ensure Long-Term ROI, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on disciplined investment policies, financial efficiency, and strategic cash banking. By tracking corridor-level returns, leveraging liquidity for operational growth, and aligning asset deployment with demand signals, Majestic transforms ROI from a static metric into a dynamic growth engine. These tactics, reinforced by partnerships, reinvestment logic, and modular scalability, ensure that every dollar invested compounds into platform resilience, corridor dominance, and hemispheric impact.
To mitigate Capital Scape, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on simulation-driven financial planning, operational leverage, and progressive vertical integration. By aligning debt terms with corridor performance, internalizing high-impact functions, and leveraging Fresh24’s ecosystem, Majestic reduces external dependency and preserves reinvestment capacity. These tactics ensure that capital remains a strategic asset, not a vulnerability, across hemispheric expansion and long-term platform evolution.
Majestic Air Cargo mitigates Tax Structure risk through a strategy built on entity optimization, jurisdictional alignment, reinvestment discipline, and intercompany governance. These tactics, reinforced by simulation-driven forecasting and treaty leverage, ensure that tax planning supports platform scalability, investor confidence, and long-term corridor dominance.

title: Team / Management risk analysis
content:
Lack of Multidisciplinary Experience Across the Admin Team: Insufficient expertise in key functional areas such as management, operations, maintenance, commercial strategy, and logistics, can lead to fragmented execution, poor decision-making, and reduced corridor performance. Unlimited Company Control from Management: Over-centralized decision-making without checks can create governance risks and strategic blind spots.
Heavy Personnel Structure: Excess staffing leads to high fixed costs, slow execution, and diluted accountability.
Founder Bottleneck Risk: Over-reliance on the founder for decisions can limit scalability and delay execution during growth phases.
Talent Retention and Continuity Risk: Loss of key personnel or institutional knowledge can disrupt operations and tech development.
Cross-Functional Misalignment: Poor coordination between departments may fragment execution and reduce corridor performance.
Cultural Misfit in Strategic Hires: Hiring experienced talent that clashes with startup pace or modular logic can reduce cohesion and impact.
To mitigate Lack of Multidisciplinary Experience Across the Admin Team, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on phased hiring, advisory support, cross-functional development, and strategic partnerships. These tactics ensure that the platform scales with precision, resilience, and founder-aligned governance.
To mitigate Heavy Personnel Structure, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on modular team design, phased hiring, automation, and strategic outsourcing. These tactics ensure that human capital scales in lockstep with corridor performance, preserving agility, margin, and operational clarity.
To mitigate Founder Bottleneck Risk, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on modular delegation, governance clarity, simulation-driven role mapping, and strategic documentation.
To mitigate Talent Retention and Continuity Risk, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on incentive alignment, knowledge continuity, career development, and cultural engagement. These tactics ensure that key personnel remain invested, empowered, and strategically embedded.
To mitigate Cultural Misfit in Strategic Hires, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on modular alignment, simulation-based validation, phased onboarding, and transparent governance logic. These tactics ensure that every strategic hire strengthens, not fragments, the platform’s cohesion, execution clarity, and hemispheric scalability.

title: Regulatory / Political risk Management
content:
Bilateral Air Service Agreement Constraints: Limited or restrictive agreements between countries can delay or block corridor activation, requiring diplomatic or regulatory negotiation.
Security & Screening Compliance: Mandatory cargo screening and aviation security protocols (e.g., TSA, CBP) can increase operational complexity and risk of shipment delays or penalties.
Environmental & Safety Regulations: Evolving emissions standards and aircraft safety requirements may force costly upgrades or restrict fleet flexibility.
Tariff Volatility & Trade Policy Shifts: Sudden changes in import/export tariffs or trade agreements can destabilize pricing, demand, and corridor economics.
Currency Controls & FX Exposure: Government-imposed currency restrictions or political instability can disrupt payments, capital flow, and financial planning.
Customs & Border Policy Changes: Shifts in customs procedures or inspection protocols can delay cargo clearance, increase spoilage risk, and reduce corridor reliability.
Political Instability in Strategic Regions: Civil unrest, elections, or regime changes may disrupt airspace access, logistics infrastructure, or regulatory continuity.
Regulatory Lag on Innovation: Slow adaptation of aviation laws to new technologies (e.g., AI routing, digital twins) can limit operational efficiency and platform optimization.
To mitigate Bilateral Air Service Agreement Constraints, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on regulatory simulation, diplomatic engagement, alliance structuring, and legal optimization.
To mitigate Security & Screening Compliance risk, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on certified facility integration, smart screening tech, chain-of-custody protocols, and compliance-driven partnerships. These tactics ensure that perishables flow securely and efficiently across corridors.
To mitigate Environmental & Safety Regulation risk, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on fleet optimization, global standards integration, hazardous cargo protocols, and simulation-driven compliance planning.
To mitigate Tariff Volatility & Trade Policy Shifts, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on dynamic pricing, supply chain diversification, treaty alignment, and simulation-driven forecasting.
To mitigate Currency Controls & FX Exposure, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy built on hedging instruments, multi-currency treasury logic, legal structuring, and simulation-driven planning.
To mitigate disruptions from shifting customs and border policies, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a layered strategy that combines advance data submission, specialized broker partnerships, and digitized documentation to streamline clearance and protect perishables. By proactively transmitting cargo data and securing expert navigation through local regulations, Majestic reduces inspection delays and ensures compliance.
To mitigate the risk of Political Instability in Strategic Regions, Majestic Air Cargo applies a proactive, multi-pronged strategy that blends intelligence, flexibility, and financial safeguards. It begins with corridor-level risk scoring to prioritize stable regions and sequence activation accordingly. Local partnerships provide real-time ground intelligence, enabling rapid response to unrest or policy shifts. Political risk insurance protects against asset loss and revenue disruption, while flexible routing ensures perishables can be redirected through compliant hubs without compromising integrity.
To mitigate Regulatory Lag on Innovation, Majestic Air Cargo deploys a strategy that blends early engagement, modular deployment, and jurisdictional targeting. By proactively collaborating with aviation authorities and industry bodies, Majestic builds trust and helps shape future standards. Innovations are introduced in modular phases to limit compliance exposure, while strategic rollout in tech-friendly regions accelerates adoption.

title: Team and Governance Team
content:
Majestic Air Cargo operates under a structured, performance-driven management system that blends hierarchical clarity with operational agility. The system is designed to support corridor-based scalability, perishables-first logistics, and continuous innovation, anchored by a leadership framework that ensures strategic alignment, rapid decision-making, and cross-platform integration.
Hierarchical Structure with Strategic Alignment
At the top of the organization is a Senior Executive Team, composed of leaders in aeronautics, advanced logistics, and innovation systems. This team sets the strategic direction for corridor activation, fleet deployment, and regulatory engagement. Their decisions are guided by simulation outputs, market intelligence, and perishables demand signals, ensuring that every initiative aligns with Majestic’s hemispheric growth model and operational priorities.
Integration with Fresh24 – Intelligence-Driven Execution
Majestic’s management system is deeply integrated with Fresh24, its perishables intelligence and demand orchestration engine. This integration is not peripheral, it’s foundational. A dedicated interface layer connects both platforms, enabling continuous data exchange around buyer/supplier dynamics, shelf-life constraints, and demand volatility.
Fresh24 provides validated requirements, such as cargo urgency, perishables sensitivity, and market-side risk, which Majestic uses to prioritize routing, adjust cargo mix, and optimize corridor sequencing. This ensures that perishables are not only moved efficiently but positioned strategically for maximum market impact.
Data-Driven Decision Making
Every layer of Majestic’s management system is powered by data visibility and simulation logic. Operational teams access live dashboards that track corridor performance, regulatory exposure, and cargo integrity. Strategic decisions, whether activating a new route or reallocating aircraft, are backed by predictive models and risk assessments.
The system also includes a Governance & Compliance Unit, which monitors regulatory changes, ESG benchmarks, and geopolitical risks. This unit feeds insight into the executive team, ensuring that decisions remain compliant, resilient, and investor ready.
Organigram Designed for Efficiency
Majestic’s organizational chart reflects a tiered but modular structure, optimized for clarity and speed. Each corridor is managed by an Activation Pod, a cross-functional team reporting to management. These pods include routing analysts, compliance officers, and perishables specialists, empowered to make tactical decisions within standardized frameworks.
The organigram ensures that strategic decisions flow top-down with precision, while operational feedback loops move bottom-up with speed. This dual flow enables Majestic to remain responsive, scalable, and aligned across all corridors and partner ecosystems.

title: IMPLEMENTATION SCHEDULE
content:
Majestic P.L.T is designed as a hemispheric logistics platform with a clear, staged growth trajectory. Its implementation unfolds across three strategic phases, each building on the operational, infrastructural, and brand foundations laid by the previous one. The program is engineered to scale regional export logistics into a fully integrated global supply and manufacturing ecosystem, anchored by perishables-first logic, corridor-based activation, and founder-centric governance.
Phase I: Continental Operations
The first phase focuses on establishing continental production, trade and logistics operations, with a strong emphasis on the Colombia–USA–Caribbean trade triangle. This corridor is selected for its high perishables density, established export protocols, and strategic proximity to key North American and island markets. Majestic will deploy certified aircraft, standardized cold chain protocols, and simulation-driven routing to ensure SLA compliance and shelf-life preservation.
Within this phase, the initial subphase centers on export operations, leveraging existing certified products, such as floriculture, fresh produce, and seafood, to build operational rhythm and corridor reliability. These exports will be routed through Majestic’s dedicated charter model, with Fresh24 providing perishables intelligence to validate urgency, shelf-life constraints, and buyer-side demand.
As these operations consolidate, Majestic will launch a Supply Development Program aimed at expanding the product portfolio across the U.S. and Latin America. This initiative will identify underutilized supply nodes, negotiate corridor access, and onboard new producers into the platform. The goal is to increase competitiveness through price optimization, access democratization, and product diversity, positioning Majestic as the preferred logistics partner for perishables across the continent.
This phase also includes the deployment of Majestic’s internal GSA to manage indirect charter flights, while remaining open to external GSAs in corridors where mutual cost, infrastructure, or efficiency advantages exist.
Phase II: Global Operations & Infrastructure Expansion
Beginning in Year 3, Majestic enters its second phase: Global Operations. This phase expands trade corridors to additional Latin American countries, including Ecuador, Peru, Brazil, Central America, and Canada, while simultaneously extending Majestic’s logistics reach to Europe and Asia. These new corridors will be activated based on perishables density, regulatory readiness, and geopolitical stability, with Fresh24 continuing to guide demand orchestration and shelf-life prioritization.
To support this expansion, Majestic will begin in-house infrastructure expansion, increasing cold storage hubs, cargo terminals, and routing nodes to reduce dependency on third-party facilities. This infrastructure will be modular, and scalable, designed to lower operational costs while increasing service reliability.
A key milestone in Phase II is Majestic’s entry into value-added manufacturing. The platform will begin processing select perishables into ready-to-market products under the Majestic brand, leveraging corridor intelligence to match product formats with regional buyer preferences. This move transforms Majestic from a logistics provider into a supply chain orchestrator, capable of delivering not just raw goods but branded, shelf-ready inventory.
Phase III: Full Vertical Integration
In Year 5, Majestic initiates its third and final phase: Full Vertical Integration. This phase is triggered by the scale and maturity of Majestic’s operational footprint, enabling the platform to internalize key services that were previously outsourced. The goal is to reduce cost exposure, increase strategic control, and unlock new revenue streams.
Key verticals include:
Maintenance, Repair, and Overhaul (MRO): Majestic’s internal maintenance division will be spun out into a certified MRO unit, servicing its own fleet and offering third-party maintenance across the region.
Flight Training Academy: Majestic will establish a training center to develop its own pilots, ground crew, and logistics specialists, ensuring talent continuity and reducing onboarding costs.
Jet Fuel Trade & Self-Supply: The platform will enter the jet fuel market, negotiating bulk supply contracts and exploring self-supply models to stabilize fuel costs across corridors.
Third-Party Service Internalization: Functions such as customs brokerage, perishables handling, and ground transport will be progressively absorbed into Majestic’s operational stack, based on volume, cost efficiency, and strategic relevance.
This phase completes Majestic’s transformation into a fully integrated hemispheric logistics and manufacturing platform, capable of controlling every aspect of the perishables supply chain, from farm to shelf, from aircraft to brand.

title: CAPITALIZATION PLAN
content:
The Majestic Program requires a total capitalization of $242 million USD, strategically disbursed over a five-year horizon to support the phased deployment of FRESH24 and Majestic Cargo. This funding structure is designed to align with corridor activation, infrastructure readiness, aircraft acquisition, and vertical integration milestones, ensuring capital efficiency and operational resilience.
Year 1 – Strategic Launch ($77 million)
Q1: FRESH24 Deployment – $22 million
The initial investment focuses on launching FRESH24’s perishables intelligence platform and establishing its core logistics nodes across the Colombia–USA–Caribbean triangle. Funds are allocated as follows:
Greensboro, NC Facilities & Technology $4.5 million
Development of perishables intake, cold chain staging, and routing simulation systems.
Gettysburg, PA Facilities & Technology – $4.5 million
Infrastructure for shelf-life validation, buyer-side analytics, and corridor orchestration.
Medellín (MDE) & Cali (CLO) Facilities – $4 million
Export-side cold chain hubs and perishables certification centers.
San Juan, PR Facility – $1.5 million
Island corridor node for perishables aggregation and last-mile routing.
Santo Domingo, DR Facility – $1 million
Strategic staging point for Caribbean corridor activation.
Operational Expenditures (OPEX) – $4 million
Covers staffing, regulatory compliance, and initial supplier onboarding.
Tech Platform Development – $2.5 million
Buildout of Fresh24’s demand orchestration engine, API layer, and simulation modules.
Q2: Majestic Cargo Launch – $55 million
This tranche initiates Majestic Cargo’s air logistics operations, enabling corridor activation and aircraft deployment.
Aircraft Acquisition (2 × A321F) – $50 million
These narrow-body freighters will service high-frequency perishables routes across the triangle.
Operational Expenditures (OPEX) – $5 million
Includes crew training, ground operations setup, and regulatory certification.
Year 2 – Expansion & Capabilities Development ($25 million)
Q1: Continental Scale-Up
Aircraft Acquisition (1 × A321F) – $20 million
Expands lift capacity for growing demand across Latin America and U.S. secondary corridors.
Remote Maintenance Facility Development – $5 million
Establishes decentralized MRO capabilities to support fleet uptime and reduce third-party dependency.
Year 3 – Global Reach & Hub Optimization ($50 million)
Q1: Intercontinental Expansion
Aircraft Acquisition (1 × B777F) – $45 million
Wide-body freighter for long-haul perishables corridors to Europe and Asia.
Ground Support Equipment & Hub Operations – $5 million
In-house cargo handling, perishables staging, in all Majestic hubs.
Year 4 – Dual Aircraft Acquisition & Brand Development ($70 million)
Q1: operational scale-up
Aircraft Acquisition (1 × B777F + 1 × A321F) – $70 million
Expands both long-haul and regional capacity to support value-added manufacturing and branded product distribution under Majestic’s label.
Year 5 – Final Fleet Consolidation ($20 million)
Aircraft Acquisition (1 × A321F) – $20 million
Final narrow-body freighter to complete Majestic’s core fleet, enabling full corridor saturation and operational redundancy.
